comments.author: Sarah
comments.content: That looks really delicious! I'm so glad you posted that because I've been trying to learn vegetarian Mexican recipes. Just one question: Do you think I could substitute red cabbage? Because I have a lot, and I don't know what to do with it.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: @Sarah - I don't see why you couldn't use red cabbage to make curtido. It would look different but I'm sure taste just as great.

comments.author: Anne
comments.content:
Thanks for the pupusa recipe! The only ones I've made were from a fat-free recipe, and the results were just as dry and tasteless as you would expect. I'll give yours a shot!

BTW, I don't usually buy these kinds of convenience foods, but I find prepackaged coleslaw mix (shredded cabbage and carrots) to be a big timesaver when I make curtido (or hot and sour soup, for that matter).

comments.author: Valen
comments.content: This is something I haven't seen before.  It looks fresh, different and tasty.  I think I will try it!

comments.author: alessandra@clear.net.nz
comments.content: Good for a winter evening in the mountains (I know it may not sound much like a Mexican landscape, but I could eat this in winter after a day skiing!)

comments.author: carol
comments.content: I LOVE pupusas!  and agree that you can't eat them without curtido.  thanks for posting both recipes, I can't wait to try it!

comments.author: Dawn (KitchenTravels)
comments.content: I made a version of these last summer with the addition of squash blossoms - delicious! Wish I could take the photo from your post and eat it for lunch. It looks so bright and fresh-tasting.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: @Dawn - wow, squash blossoms sound  fantastic in them!

comments.author: sarah (braise and butter)
comments.content: oh HURRAH. thank you for this! there are a ton of pupusa places in the dc area, some stellar, some not-so-much. i love them, but have been wanting to give them a shot at home so i can control what's going in. so excited :)

comments.author: Lizzie
comments.content: Feta is another non-traditional cheese that works really well to fill pupusas.  I make them all the time to feed all of my friends and roommates; they can never wait until I am finished to start eating!

comments.author: Rebecca- Guasave Sinaloa Mx
comments.content:
I found this by surfing the web! Absolutely great. The taste was so close to ones my friends make they were surprised.
Gret web site.

comments.author: Brad
comments.content: Please recognize that THESE ARE NOT FROM MEXICO (not everything on the web containing ingredients commonly used in mexican foods is from mexico. Pupusas for example are from the country El Salvador.)

comments.author: AA
comments.content: Pupusas are NOT mexican..... Pupusas are from El Salvador!!!!!

comments.author: AA
comments.content: Thank you!!! I hate when people think that everything that looks spanish is mexican.

comments.author: TRACIE
comments.content: I LOVE EL SALVADOR!!!!

comments.author: jessica
comments.content: i love el Salvador food but also mexican food because both foods are great

comments.author: jessica
comments.content: not all people think that way it is just because people dont see how good food from El  Salvador taste good

comments.author: jessica
comments.content: FYI  it does not matter because Mexican people like the food anyways that we Salvadorean people make

comments.author: Griselda
comments.content:
I'm half Salvadorian and I don't find it ok to call our pupusas stuffed tortillas because they are not tortillas, I would appreciate if you change the title. This dish is only Salvadorian.
You forgot to include the tomato salsa that goes on top of the curtido. its a very simply salsa not spicy at all. 
Pupusas can also be made of rice flour and they can also contain a variety of other stuffings like chicharron (pork), squash blossom, loroco, shrimp, fish, cheese, beans with cheese, revueltas (pork, cheese and beans) depending on the region of El Salvador. 
Pupusas are my favorite dish from El Salvador, you will all love them. There are many other great dishes like the Salvadorian tamales wrapped in banana lives made from a tender strained masa very popular in central america. The plantain empanadas stuffed with milk pudding or black beans, stuff meat peppers, turkey sandwich, meat picadillo turnovers, fried plantains, sopa de pata (cow feet soup), yucca with pork, the quesadilla bread, the horchata drink, fruit salad drink

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: You are totally right, filled tortilla isn't a very good description. I was looking for something that would help someone who hasn't had them before get a basic idea of what they are. I'm open to other ideas! And if you want to mention your recipe for the tomato salsa I'm sure people would love to know.
